description: From Middle English heren, from Old English hīeran (“to hear”), from Proto-West Germanic *hauʀijan, from Proto-Germanic *hauzijaną (“to hear”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ḱh₂owsyéti (“to be sharp-eared”), from *h₂eḱ- (“sharp”) + *h₂ows- (“ear”) + *-yéti (denominative suffix).

verbs.description: hear (third-person singular simple present hears, present participle hearing, simple past and past participle heard)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, stative) To perceive sounds through the ear. [from 10th c.]
examples: I was deaf, and now I can hear.

entries.meaning: (transitive, stative) To perceive (a sound, or something producing a sound) with the ear, to recognize (something) in an auditory way. [from 10th c.]
examples: I heard a sound from outside the window.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To exercise this faculty intentionally; to listen to. [from 10th c.]
(transitive) To listen favourably to; to grant (a request etc.). [from 10th c.]
examples: Eventually the king chose to hear her entreaties.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To receive information about; to come to learn of. [from 10th c.]
(transitive, law) To listen to (a person, case) in a court of law; to try. [from 12th c.]
examples: Your case will be heard at the end of the month.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To sympathize with; to understand the feelings or opinion of.
examples: You're tired of all the ads on TV? I hear ya.
